newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: Sierra Leone president meets rebel leader.
newsitem.headline: Sierra Leone president meets rebel leader.

text.p: Sierra Leone's president, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, and rebel leader Foday Sankoh met in Ivory Coast on Thursday and Sankoh said afterwards he was keen to return home to seek a fresh mandate from his fighters to talk peace.

The Sierra Leone government, in a statement issued in the capital Freetown, said Kabbah had agreed to Sankoh returning with international observers but set a December 1 deadline for completing the peace process.
Sankoh, in remarks to reporters later, accused the Kabbah government of breaching a truce in force since March.
"We do respect the ceasefire but Kabbah and his government is not respecting the ceasefire," he said, adding he had been waiting to talk to his fighters for the past six months.
"I need to renew my mandate from my combatants and the People's War Council for further negotiations or signing any peace accord with the so-called government in Freetown."
Sankoh said he wanted representatives of the United Nations, the Organisation of African Unity, the Commonwealth and other international organisations to accompany him.
The Freetown government said Kabbah agreed to the request. Sankoh said he hoped to leave in early November.
Ivorian President Henri Konan Bedie chaired the meeting in the commercial capital Abidjan.

A senior military official said in Freetown earlier that the army had knocked out a rebel communications and logistics base in the north, near the strategic highway from Freetown to the second town of Bo. He said troops killed 60 rebels.
Eyewitnesses said mercenaries from a private South African security firm had led the attack.

Kabbah took over in April when the army restored civilian rule after four years in power. A string of attacks blamed on the rebels, who took up arms in 1991, has put the truce under strain but neither side has spoken of abandoning it.
